entry.title: Simple Linearizations of the Simple Pendulum for Any Amplitude
entry.summary: Two simple, interpolatory-like linearizations are shown for the simple pendulum which can be used for any initial amplitude.

entry.title: Gauge Invariance and Canonical Variables
entry.summary: We discuss some paradoxes arising due to the gauge-dependence of canonical variables in mechanics.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, latex, no figures, Siberian Journal of Physics, in press

entry.title: Averages of static electric and magnetic fields over a spherical region: a derivation based on the mean-value theorem
entry.summary: Submitted to "Notes and Discussions" in American Journal of Physics.

entry.title: Classical Electrodynamics
entry.summary: Excerpts are presented from a graduate course on Classical Electrodynamics held during the spring semester of 2000 at the Institute of Physics, Guanajuato State University, Mexico

entry.title: Compactification of the moduli space in symplectization and hidden symmetries of its boundary
entry.summary: In this paper, we establish the compactification of the moduli space in symplectization and and studied the hidden symmetries of its boundary.

entry.title: Kinematics on oblique axes
entry.summary: We solve a difficult problem involving velocity and acceleration components along oblique axes, and propose two problems of central force motion to be solved using oblique axes.

entry.title: Expressing Maxwell's equations independently of the unit system
entry.summary: A procedure to teach Electrodynamics independently of unit systems is presented and compared with some of those given in physics literature.

entry.title: A Formula for Gauge Invariant Reduction of Electromagnetic Multipole Tensors
entry.summary: Based on some previous results, one gives a general formula for introducing electromagnetic multipole expansions in terms of symmetric and traceless cartesian tensors.

entry.title: The Image of a Wormhole
entry.summary: A wormhole is a hypothetical tunnel through space. We employ the techniques taught in a standard calculus course to generate the images (embedding diagrams) of the Schwarzschild Wormhole and the Thorne-Morris Wormhole.

entry.title: Evaluating the Root-Mean-Squared of a Sinusoidal Signal Without Using Calculus
entry.summary: The frequently mentioned root-mean-squared value of an alternating voltage is derived without using calculus.

entry.title: Textos de Fisica para professores e estudantes--II
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn by the author.
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn by the author

entry.title: The Postulates of Quantum Mechanics
entry.summary: As a starting point in understanding Quantum Mechanics, the postulates of Quantum Mechanics are presented, and few of the main eigenvalue problems, as well.

entry.title: Some rules of good scientific writing
entry.summary: A non-native English speaking physics professor formulates obvious yet useful rules for writing research papers.

entry.title: A study of resistance forces
entry.summary: In this paper we present an example of a simple study of velocity proportional resistance force. Some experimental determinations are presented.

entry.title: Quantifying Student Effort and Class Involvement in the Introductory Higher Education Science Classroom
entry.summary: This note details a minimal effort program, Cash Participation, that quantifies class participation while increasing class energy, decreasing student apathy and removing student embraced anonymity.

entry.title: Improving physics with CanSat
entry.summary: The european CanSat competition is a funny way to understand physics. My students used low budget sensors and data analysis testing a model for temperature and humidity in low troposphere.

entry.title: The Quantized Hall Effect. (Lab Tutorial. In German.)
entry.summary: This paper is a lab tutorial (and a theory primer) for the integral quantum Hall effect experiment as conducted at Applied Solid State Physics, University of Bochum, Germany.

entry.title: Aberration and Special Relativity
entry.summary: Section 7 of Einstein's 1905 electrodynamics paper gives frequency-shift and aberration formulae that together describe an elongated ellipsoidal wavefront. A Lorentz contraction of this ellipsoid solves most (but not all) of the associated relativistic problems.
entry.arxiv:comment: Approximately 2300 words, with three figures. Nine GIFs, including equations. Submitted to Am.J.Phys. on 03/Jun/98; eric_baird@compuserve.com

entry.title: Intrinsic Kinematics
entry.summary: We show how some geometric elements of the path of a particle moving in a plane -- the osculating circle and its radius of curvature -- can be used to construct the parabolic trajectory of projectiles in motion under gravity.

entry.title: Post-Gaussian variational method for quantum anharmonic oscillator
entry.summary: Using the post-Gaussian trial functions, we calculate the variational solutions to the quantum-mechanical anharmonic oscillator. We evaluate not only the ground state but also some excited energies, and compare them with numerical results.

entry.title: Classical Mechanics
entry.summary: This is the English version of a friendly graduate course on Classical Mechanics, containing about 80% of the material I covered during the January-June 1999 semester at IFUG in the Mexican city of Leon. For the Spanish version, see physics/9906066

entry.title: An elementary quantum mechanics calculation for the Casimir effect in one dimension
entry.summary: We obtain the Casimir effect for the massless scalar field in one dimension based on the analogy between the quantum field and the continuum limit of an infinite set of coupled harmonical oscillators.

entry.title: Compendium of vector analysis with applications to continuum mechanics
entry.summary: 1. Connection between integration and differentiation/ Gauss theorem. Coordinate-free definitions: gradient, divergence, curl. Stokes theorem. 2. Elements of continuum mechanics/ Continuity equation. Stress tensor. Euler equation. Hydrodynamics. Elasticity.

entry.title: Effective Field Theory for Pedestrians
entry.summary: A pedagological introduction to effective field theory is presented.
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 Pages, 2 figures, Invited talk given at the Millennium School on Nuclear and Particle Physics, National Acceleration Centre, Faure, South Africa, 31 January to 3 February 2000

entry.title: A bubble theorem
entry.summary: Proof of a simple mathematical inequality using elements of surface tension theory and ideal gas law to the formation and coalescence of bubbles.
entry.arxiv:comment: Latex style convention for mathematics magazine
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Mathematics Magazine, volume 73, number 5, pages 396-397, December 2000

entry.title: Complexity: An Introduction
entry.summary: This article summarises a Web-book on "Complexity" that was developed to introduce undergraduate students to interesting complex systems in the biological, physical and social sciences, and the common tools, principles and concepts used for their study.

entry.title: Trotter formula and thermodynamic limits
entry.summary: We discuss the interchangeability of the thermodynamic limit \beta \to \infty and the infinite limit of the Trotter number n \to \infty when Trotter formula e^{H_{0}+V} =\lim_{n \to \infty} (e^{H_{0}/n} e^{V/n}) is used to calculate partition functions with Hamiltonians of the form H=H_{0}+V.

entry.title: Can we derive the Lorentz force from Maxwell's equations?
entry.summary: The Lorentz force can be obtained from Maxwell's equations in the Coulomb gauge provided that we assume that the electric portion of the force acted on a charge is known, and the magnetic component is perpendicular to the velocity of motion of the charged particle.

entry.title: Where Did the Laws of Physics Come From?
entry.summary: This paper was withdrawn by the author.

entry.title: The Nobel Prize in Physics 2002 for the observation of cosmic neutrinos
entry.summary: A brief description of the work for which the first half of the Nobel prize for physics for the year 2002 is presented.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages plain latex, to appear in Resonance, Journal of Science Education

entry.title: A Note on Derivation of Rutherford Formula within Born Approximation
entry.summary: It is shown in this paper that one does not need to use just exponential dumping factor when computing the Rutherford formula within Born approximation. Text, which is very simple, might be of interest for physics students as well as for physics teachers.

entry.title: Some Remarks about Variable Mass Systems
entry.summary: We comment about the general argument given to obtain the rocket equation as it is exposed in standard textbooks. In our opinion, it can induce students to a wrong answer when solving variable mass problems.

entry.title: Lorentz Invariance of Neutrino Oscillations
entry.summary: It is shown that, in spite of the appearances, the standard expression for the oscillation probability of ultrarelativistic neutrinos is Lorentz invariant.

entry.title: A comment on W. Greiner's "Quantum Mechanics -- An Introduction"
entry.summary: It is pointed out that in Greiner's book, ``Quantum Mechanics --An Introduction,'' there is a confusion between the wavelength spectral function and the (angular) frequency spectral function in the derivation of the Wien's displacement law.

entry.title: Expressing the power radiated by electric charged systems
entry.summary: After a systematic introduction of some formulae for the energy radiated by localized electric charges and currents, one considers the multipole radiation and the reduction of the multipole tensors to the symmetric traceless ones.

entry.title: The rules of coherence and other habits
entry.summary: Physics and mathematics are difficult enough without the aditional burden of bad habits. In this article, we examine some helpful habits that tend to be underemphasized by many physics teachers (mainly because they seem so obvious!).

entry.title: A Scaling Approach to Ideal Quantum Gases
entry.summary: The thermodynamic properties of ideal quantum gases are derived solely from dimensional arguments, the Pauli principle and thermodynamic relations, without resorting to statistical mechanics.

entry.title: Influence and Inference in Bell's Theorem
entry.summary: Jaynes' criticism of Bell's theorem is examined. It is found that Bell's reasoning leading to his theorem is sound when properly interpreted. The nature of physical influence and logical inference in quantum mechanics, and its relationship with the notions of realism and locality, is discussed.

entry.title: Special Relativity for the School Going Child
entry.summary: An elementary account of special relativity for school-children.

author.name: T. P. Singh
author.arxiv:affiliation: Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai

entry.arxiv:comment: 15 pages, two figures. Elementary Article meant for 12-15 year old schoolchildren. Published by TIFR, Mumbai in `A revolution in physics: Einstein's 1905 discoveries made simple'

entry.title: Some Aspects of the Electromagnetic Multipole Expansions
entry.summary: Various procedures for expressing the multipolar expansion of the electromagnetic field are considered with application to the calculation of the radiated power. Some results from literature are discussed and perspective of developing the subject is pointed out.

entry.title: On the Use of Relativistic Mass in Various Published Works
entry.summary: A lengthy bibliography of books referring to special and/or general relativity is provided to give a background for discussions on the historical use of the concept of relativistic mass.

entry.title: A Simple General Solution for Maximal Horizontal Range of Projectile Motion
entry.summary: A convenient change of variables in the problem of maximizing the horizontal range of the projectile motion, with an arbitrary initial vertical position of the projectile, provides a simple, straightforward solution.

entry.title: Misconceptions on Relativity Gravitation and Cosmology
entry.summary: Fifteen misconceptions involving Relativity, Gravitation and Cosmology are exposed, along with corrections
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages including front page. Replaced with enlarged text, and new title

entry.title: Thermal Expansion Puzzles
entry.summary: The standard formula that describes the thermal expansion of a solid creates several puzzles for discerning students. Three puzzles are reviewed, and their common resolution discussed both conceptually and quantitatively.

entry.title: Path Integral and the Induction Law
entry.summary: We show how the induction law is correctly used in the path integral computation of the free particle propagator. The way this primary path integral example is treated in most textbooks is a little bit missleading.

entry.title: Do we have enough air?
entry.summary: If only human beings would breathe the entire quantity of terrestrial air, then, at the present-day population on the Earth, one million years would exhaust that air. It seems we have enough air. Is it so?

entry.title: Is Peudoscience the Solution to Science Literacy?
entry.summary: Brief overview of the `Pseudoscience' flavor of the `Physics in Films' project at the University of Central Florida.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 2 columns. Appeared in the EISTA05 proceedings

entry.title: Comment on Development and assessment of research-based tutorials on heat engines and the second law of thermodynamics, by Matthew J. Cochran and Paula R. L. Heron, Am. J. Phys. 74, 734--741 (2006)
entry.summary: A diagram that represents both conservation of energy and constancy of entropy in Carnot cycle.

entry.title: Verification of the Rayleigh Scattering Cross Section
entry.summary: A simple experiment is described for the direct determination of the wavelength dependence of the Rayleigh scattering cross section using the classical example of the blue sky.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: American Journal of Physics, Volume 75, Issue 9, pp. 824-826 (2007)

entry.title: The physical meaning of Lagrange multipliers
entry.summary: A rule to assign a physical meaning to Lagrange multipliers is discussed. Examples from mechanics, statistical mechanics and quantum mechanics are given.

entry.title: Voltage Controlled Resistance
entry.summary: The paper discusses an application of the field effected transistor (FET) as a voltage controlled resistance which can be done in under-graduate labs either as a routine experiment or as a project.

entry.title: Heuristic model of teaching
entry.summary: A simple physical model differentiates effective from ineffective teaching and identifies elements that make teaching productive, with specific implications concerning training of teachers.
entry.arxiv:comment: 24 pages, revtex4, multiple editorial changes, added a reference

entry.title: Putnam Physics Competition: a suggestion
entry.summary: I bring to the attention of the physics community the non-existence of a Putnam Physics Competition in North America despite the fact that the Putnam Mathematical Competition has been well known and highly successful for 70 years.

entry.title: Physics education research: Resources for middle school science teachers
entry.summary: This resource letter intends to provide middle school science teachers with a collection of resources to aid them in planning and implementing a physical science curriculum. The resources are in the form of books, websites, journals, and organizations.

entry.title: Lessons in Particle Physics
entry.summary: Lecture notes for an introductory course in elementary particles.

entry.title: Teaching and Learning Science with Learning Assistants
entry.summary: The science content classes for elementary education majors at Winona State University used Learning Assistants for the first time during the 2009 - 2010 academic year. Pre-post information was gathered about the Learning Assistants and the pre-service teachers to gauge the effect of this experience on both populations.

entry.title: Physics Education Research and the Teaching and Learning of Physics
entry.summary: A brief account of some recent controversies about the teaching and learning of physics is presented. A shorter version of this outcome was accepted by The Physics Teacher, but publication is still pending.

entry.title: Electroluminescence in photovoltaic cell
entry.summary: Here we propose two methods to get electroluminescence images from photovoltaic cells in a school or home lab.

entry.title: Illuminating Fourier Series with Audacity
entry.summary: This paper briefly describes some simple techniques for illuminating Fourier series and Fourier analysis with the Audacity sound recording program. These techniques are easily applied in the classroom and help students move beyond formula roulette in their understanding of Fourier techniques.

entry.title: A Mathematical Modeling In Computer Algebra Systems (CAS) As A Base For A Development of The Mathematics Education
entry.summary: Information technologies for studying physical-mathematical disciplines on base of mathematical modeling in the computer algebra system Maple are described.

entry.title: Closing the Gap between Teaching and Assessment
entry.summary: Evidence-based teaching is based upon a model of learning in which assessment plays a central role.
entry.arxiv:comment: written for the report of the Association of American Universities (AAU) Workshop on Effective Evaluation of Teaching and Learning with an invited presentation titled: Closing the gap between teaching and assessment

entry.title: Renormalizing Recitation Grades
entry.summary: I discuss issue of how to adjust recitation grades given by different instructors in a large course, taking into account and correcting for differences in standards among the instructors, while preserving the effects of differences in average student performance among the recitation sections.

entry.title: Excitons with anisotropic effective mass
entry.summary: We present a simple analytic scheme for calculating the binding energy of excitons in semiconductors that takes full account of the existing anisotropy in the effective mass, as a complement to the qualitative treatment in most textbooks. Results obtained for excitons in gallium nitride form the basis for a discussion of the accuracy of this approach.

entry.title: Teaching Newton with anticipation(...)
entry.summary: Care making only clock-specific assertions about elapsed-time, and other ``space-time smart'' strategies from the perspective of a selected inertial map-frame, open doors to an understanding of anyspeed motion via application of the metric equation.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages (6 figs, 6 refs) RevTeX for broadened readership; http://www.umsl.edu/~fraundor/a1toc.html

entry.title: Have We At Last Found The A-toms?
entry.summary: It is argued that the three families of quarks and leptons are the building blocks of all matter and all forces (leaving out gravity) among them are mediated by photons ($\gamma$), the weak bosons ($W^\pm$ and $Z$) and the gluons.

entry.title: Statistical Mechanics in a Nutshell
entry.summary: I give a concise introduction to some essential concepts of statistical mechanics: 1. Probability theory (constrained distributions, concentration theorem, frequency estimation, hypothesis testing); 2. Macroscopic systems in equilibrium (macrostate, thermodynamic variables, entropy, first law, thermodynamic potentials, correlations); 3. Linear response (Kubo formula).
entry.arxiv:comment: Lecture Notes (Part I of a course on "Transport Theory" taught at Dresden University of Technology, Spring 1997), 23 pages; more info at http://www.mpipks-dresden.mpg.de/~jochen/transport/intro.html

entry.title: World Wide Student Laboratory. Description of Project
entry.summary: This paper describes a new framework in educational technology - the World Wide Student Laboratory (WWSL) Project. WWSL is a dynamic international Internet-based collaboration of resourses of educational and research labs of universities, institutions, government research centers and companies. The concepts of the WWSL are outlined, a possible idea for structure is discussed and examples of various WWSL studies are shown.

entry.title: A Problem of Relative, Constrained Motion
entry.summary: We develop a new method to determine the acceleration of a block sliding down along the face of a moving wedge. We have been able to link the solution of this problem to that of the inclined plane problem of elementary physics, thus providing a simpler solution to it.

entry.title: Finite Rotations
entry.summary: We present an elementary discussion of two basic properties of angular displacements, namely, the anticommutation of finite rotations and the commutation of infinitesimal rotations, and show how commutation is achieved as the angular displacements get smaller and smaller.

entry.title: Universality of the Hohenberg-Kohn functional
entry.summary: We comment on a recent article by H. L. Neal [Am. J. Phys. 66, 512 (1998)], in which an analytic expression for the Hohenberg-Kohn functional was derived for one-dimensional two-particle systems with the harmonic interaction. We argue that the functional given by Neal is not exact but really constitutes an approximation in the same spirit as the local-density approximation.

entry.title: Difficult Problems Having Easy Solutions
entry.summary: We discuss how a class of difficult kinematic problems can play an important role in an introductory course in stimulating students' reasoning on more complex physical situations. The problems presented here have an elementary analysis once certain symmetry features of the motion are revealed. We also explore some unexpected directions these problems lead us.

entry.title: MY LIFE AS TUTOR: Reflections on Two Recent Experiences
entry.summary: In this final report, I briefly reflect on two parallel teaching experiences as tutor. Besides, I briefly view such experiences in interaction with my research work, private life and new teaching position. In harmony with my conception of teaching, I avoid the standard formal style of reports and try an interactive dialogue with the reader.

entry.title: Mecanica Clasica (Classical Mechanics)
entry.summary: First Internet graduate course on Classical Mechanics in Spanish (Castellano). This is about 80% of the material I covered during the January-June 1999 semester at IFUG in the Mexican city of Leon. English and Romanian versions are in (slow) progress and hopefully will be arXived. For a similar course on Quantum Mechanics, see physics/9808031

entry.title: Oscar's Physics Phaire: A Collection of Problems
entry.summary: You will find here a number of (mostly) elementary physics problems dealing mainly with uniform motion kinematics. In preparing this collection I have tried to create original situations that could help bring motivation to an introductory course. You are welcome to suggest improvements and ... provide solutions!

entry.title: Winning Over Future Scientists
entry.summary: A review of existing pre-college science programs for young women in high school is presented,with emphasis on the University of Rochester Pre-College Experience in Physics summer program for 9th and 10th grade high school women (PREP-CMS). A new model for such programs is proposed.

author.name: Julie Fry
author.arxiv:affiliation: Department of Physics and Astronomy and Department of Chemistry, University of Rochester, NY

entry.arxiv:comment: 21 pages, to be submitted to Journal of Women and Minorities in Science

entry.title: Solidification pipes: from solder pots to igneous rocks
entry.summary: When a substance that shrinks in volume as it solidifies (for example, lead) is melted in a container and then cooled, a deep hole is often found in the center after resolidification. We use a simple model to describe the shape of the pipe and compare it with experimental results.

entry.title: Lagrangians and Hamiltonians for High School Students
entry.summary: A discussion of Lagrangian and Hamiltonian dynamics is presented at a level which should be suitable for advanced high school students. This is intended for those who wish to explore a version of mechanics beyond the usual Newtonian treatment in high schools, but yet who do not have advanced mathematical skills.

entry.title: The Precessing Top
entry.summary: I discuss the precession motion of a symmetrical top without the assumption that its precessional velocity is much smaller than its spin angular velocity. I derive the general formula for the precessional velocity in an elementary way and discuss the cases of slow and fast precessions.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: The Physics Teacher, 38, N5, May 2000, p.312

entry.title: A new solution for inflation
entry.summary: Many pedagogical introductions of cosmological inflation are effective due to the simplicity of the relevant equations. Here an analytic solution of the cosmological equations is presented and used as an example to discuss fundamental aspects of the inflationary paradigm.
entry.arxiv:comment: 14 pages, LaTeX, to appear in Am. J. Phys

entry.title: The easiest way to Heaviside ellipsoid
entry.summary: The formula for the electric field of a point charge moving with constant velocity is derived using the symmetry properties of Maxwell's equations - its Lorentz invariance. In contrast to conventional treatments, the derivation presented does not use retarded integrals or relativity transformations.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: American Journal of Physics, Vol. 70, No. 7, pp. 717--718, July 2002

entry.title: A simple Solvable Model of Body Motion in a One-dimensional Resistive Medium
entry.summary: We introduce and solve in closed form a simple model of a macroscopic body propagating in a one-dimensional resistive medium at temperature T. The assumption of completely inelastic collisions between the body and the particles composing the medium leads to a resistive force that is opposite and proportional to the square of the body's velocity
entry.arxiv:comment: Sybmitted to Eur. J. of Phys., nine pages, three figures

entry.title: Mecanica Relacional: A proposito de uma resenha
entry.summary: We present a critical analysis of what is called Relational Mechanics, as it has been presented in a book thus entitled, which has been recently reviewed in this journal.
entry.arxiv:comment: 24 pages, latex, no figures, in portuguese
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Revista Brasileira de Ensino de Fisica vol. 23 (3), 260 (2001)

entry.title: How simple is simple pendulum
entry.summary: The simple pendulum is one of the first experiments that students of higher physics do. There are certain precautions which the students are asked to take while performing the experiment. In this note we will try to explain as to why these precautions are taken up and what will happen if we relax them.

entry.title: How to Introduce A World Time to A Part of Two Dimensional de Sitter Manifold
entry.summary: We define 1+1 dimensional de Sitter manifold in this paper and we consider various coordinate systems on it. Some interesting aspects of the general theory of relativity are demonstrated by using the transformations between the considered coordinate systems. The problem might be of interest for physics and mathematics students as well as for physics teachers.

entry.title: Direction dependency of extraordinary refraction index
entry.summary: A simple experiment is presented that enables qualitative and quantitative measurement of the extraordinary refractive index direction dependency in an uniaxial nematic liquid crystal. Three liquid crystaline cells were designed in which elongated molecules of nematic liquid crystal align in directions which enable to observe the variation of extraordinary refractive index as a function of the direction of light.

entry.title: Trajectory of the harmonic oscillator in the Schreodinger wave
entry.summary: A trajectory of a harmonic oscillator obeying the Schreodinger wave equation is exactly derived and illustrated. The trajectory resembles well the classical orbit between the turning points, and also runs through the tunneling region. The dynamics of the `particle' motion and the wave function associated with the motion are proposed. The period of a round trip on the trajectory is exactly equal to that obtained in classical mechanics.

entry.title: Linearisation of Simple Pendulum
entry.summary: The motion of a pendulum is described as Simple Harmonic Motion (SHM) in case the initial displacement given is small. If we relax this condition then we observe the deviation from the SHM. The equation of motion is non-linear and thus difficult to explain to under-graduate students. This manuscript tries to simplify things.

author.name: P. Arun
author.arxiv:affiliation: Department of Physics & Astrophysics, University of Delhi, India

author.name: Naveen Gaur
author.arxiv:affiliation: Department of Physics & Astrophysics, University of Delhi, India

entry.title: Enhancing science education in the elementary schools
entry.summary: This article describes some collaborative activities of the authors, aimed at improving science education in elementary schools. These include curriculum enhancement, development of new apparatus (a wind tunnel), science-education web site contributions and production of a film about the physics of flight. The output of these projects is intended to be generally accessible or reproducible.
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in the American Journal of Physics, 3 pages

entry.title: Student Resources in Quantum Mechanics, or Why Students Need Meta-resources
entry.summary: We are trying to identify resources students are using to reason in quantum mechanics. In this process we realize students must have not only the right resources available but sophisticated for evaluating and controlling their thought processes. We will discuss examples from student interviews to illustrate our point.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, No figures, Submitted to the Physics Education Research Conference Proceedings, 2002

entry.title: The physics of stone skipping
entry.summary: The motion of a stone skimming over a water surface is considered. A simplified description of the collisional process of the stone with water is proposed. The maximum number of bounces is estimated by considering both the slowing down of the stone and its angular stability. The conditions for a successful throw are discussed.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages, 5 figures (to appear in American Journal of Physics)

entry.title: Listening to the coefficient of restitution and the gravitational acceleration of a bouncing ball
entry.summary: We show that a well known method for measuring the coefficient of restitution of a bouncing ball can also be used to obtain the gravitational acceleration.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, 5 figures, to be published in Am. J. Phys

entry.title: Teaching with Physlets: Examples from Optics
entry.summary: Physlets are scriptable Java applets that can be used for physics instruction. In this article we discuss the pedagogical foundations of Physlet use and provide a sample of Physlet-based exercises that could be used to teach optics.
entry.arxiv:comment: Published in The Physics Teacher, November 2002, pp. 494-499. 9 pages, 7 figures
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Dancy, M., Christian, W. & Belloni, M. (2002). Teaching with Physlets: Examples from optics. The Physics Teacher, 40(8). 494-499

entry.title: Effect of the spherical Earth on a simple pendulum
entry.summary: We consider the period of a simple pendulum in the gravitational field of the spherical Earth. Effectively, gravity is enhanced compared with the often used flat Earth approximation, such that the period of the pendulum is shortened. We discuss the flat Earth approximation, and show when the corrections due to the spherical Earth may be of interest.

entry.title: An Approximate Expression for the Large Angle Period of a Simple Pendulum
entry.summary: A heuristic but pedagogical derivation is given of an explicit formula which accurately reproduces the period of a simple pendulum even for large amplitudes. The formula is compared with others in the literature.

entry.title: Comment on "Phase Transition-Like Behavior in a Low-Pass Filter"
entry.summary: This is a reminder that an infinite series can be defined other than as the limit of a sequence of finite series. An example is provided in which a circuit element comprised of an infinite series of resistors has negative resistance.

author.name: Jack L. Uretsky
author.arxiv:affiliation: High Energy Physics Division, Argonne National Laboratory
